name: silk Shibori pleated ribbon-colorway gingko
description:
introducing the colorway "ginko" and my small tribute to it's changing leaves-a rearranging of sorts from fall to winter here.

seasonally available

10 yards available now. by the yard

name: indigo and porcelain wristlet or anklet
description:
recipe for an indigo wristlet:

a little linen selvedge (scrap)
an indigo fermentation vat (natural)
some time in the woods with the basket makers (reflection and twining)
a walk on the beach in Hayama, Japan (gathering porcelain & beach glass)
hand dyed threads (for wrapping and sewing)
a spot of glue and a button back.

a little time and space

no two alike- 8 inches.  if you need one a little larger let me know...

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: pomegranate and indigo
description:
small collection of vintage silks and cotton dyed first in the pomegranate and then in indigo. golds and greens.  

2 skeins of silk thread too.

one only for now.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

description:
a lavender filled indigo pincushion thoughtfully stitched and dyed by my hand. 

comes with 2 skeins of indigo dyed silk thread.  

(about 5"x6")

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: Arashi Shibori Silk Wraps
description:
AKA Chou (butterfly) Silk Shibori Scarf

Basic info:

These are all one of a kind and hand dyed silk. 6 momme (lightweight) habutai dyed in the arashi shibori tradition.  This means they are pole wrapped which creates both the texture and the dye pattern simultaneously.  The dye and the pleating are steam set. They can be dyed in many wonderful and custom color combinations. On each scarf point I stitch on a crystal bead.

I call these Chou scarves as they are light and colorful as butterfly wings and a light breeze adds movement as you wear them.  As I was photographing them today they reminded me of octopus swirling in the ocean's current.  Either way, they are ready to find their way to you and brighten up your wardrobe.

Dry clean only to retain the pleats. 

45" x 84" before pleating for the regular length
45" x 108" before pleating for the extra long version 

Currently available on a "dyed to order" basis only through the holidays-please allow 3 weeks.  

Since these are made entirely by me and the days being only 24 hours long, there are only so many I can produce and still maintain the attention to detail I desire to apply to each piece.  
.  
I also have a short slideshow on the blog with images of recently dyed pieces:
http://wp.me/p1S6h-1sw

name: silk thread
description:
I came across this silk thread from India and have been putting some in the fabric collections recently.  It is really lovely and just the right weight for me.  

each skein is 100 yards and is 2 ply single strand thread.  

here I am offering full skeins in indigo as well indigo and pomegranate. solids and ombre'd.  hand dyed here of course in the indigo fermentation vat and pomegranates from the back yard.

seasonally offered.

a nice addition to "naturally shiborigirl".  these will ship in about a week.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: indigo silk ombre scarf
description:
silk scarf from Kiryu area of Japan.  very sheer with stripe and fringe.  indigo ombre dyed. stripe is heavier fiber in the warp of the piece.

like air,  hand washable

aprox.  24" x 72"

these two listed are darker on one end that the other so when wearing different lovely shades of indigo grace each end. dyed in both my current natural fermentation vats.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: aobana pens from Japan
description:
These aobana pens will mark your fabric and then wash out during the wetting out and dyeing process.  These are the pens we use in my shibori classes to line out designs before stitching.  

Aobana is a fugitive dye made from a blue flower.  

(please note that these items have a $0 shipping cost when ordered with another item)

name: carry the moon bag
description:
some days you just want to carry the moon with you.

this indigo dyed and lined stitched bag is 4"x7" with a min. 48" long strap and  swivel attachment.  (you can adjust the length if desired by cutting the strap and re-tying it to the loop.) 

the opening features a spring frame-just squeeze the sides and the frame opens up. the interior is lined with indigo dyed cotton.  

big enough- but not too big to carry the moon, a thought, a prayer, a memory (also fits an iphone, a bit of money, cards, just the essentials.  also makes a nice bag to carry needle, thread, sm.scissors, thimble ) 

strap is sized to wear across your body and leave your hands free. 

fabrics are cotton, silk, and linen. some found, some donated.  all indigo dyed here.  piecing hand stitched with silk thread-body and lining machine sewn for strength.

there are only two left- between photographing and listing one found a new home...but three are seen in the group photo. (the design order is 1-2-3 in the main photo and the two remaining photos show the front and backs of bag 2 & 3 respectively.)

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: indigo silk double edged ombre scarf
description:
indigo, ombre'd on both outer edges leaving pure white silk in the center.

beautiful delicate open weave silk with slubs, narrow width yardage from Japan.
fringed ends.

soft, simple, classic.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: silk mawata from Japan
description:
These are silk mawata (hankies) from Japan and produced with silk grown in the Gunma prefecture.  On the recent Silk Study tour to Japan we had the privilege of visiting the sericulture farm of one of Japan's oldest and most knowledgable silk farmers, Koyata san.  In addition, the Tama Silk Life 21 Research Group  instructed us on sericulture, silk reeling, silk spinning, mawata making, and making silk quilt batting.  

THese mawata were made by their group to support their work and are really, really beautiful.

name: handmade Japanese brush
description:
Several people have asked me for a source for this brush when I teach shibori.  The one I have was given to me by a kanoko shibori master which he used to transfer aobana to the cloth through a stencil.  It is handmade and over 100 years old.  

Recently in Japan I saw some of these brushes being sold in a dye shop and brought back several extras.  They do come in several sizes but this is the size most like the old one I own.  

Surprisingly, these new ones are very similar to the old ones, even after all these years.  I find them useful when applying dye to arashi poles, in indigo dyeing as well as for transferring aobana to the cloth through a stencil.  The many hairs allow you to work dye into the cloth using a circular motion.  

Plus, they are just a lovely reminder of the past.

I was told by one brush seller that you can add some glue to the back (non-working)side of the bristles to keep the hairs from falling out over time.  I notice that some brushes have been treated this way.  Makes sense.  I will try some wood glue on mine.

name: more dyeable vintage cloth
description:
wondering what if? wondering in white?  or maybe even in indigo blue?

cloth containing texture as a main component, fragments like scattered thoughts across time and place, imperfection seen as perfection.

these fabric collections contain an array of all vintage natural fabrics gleaned from here and there and thoughtfully assembled to rework, dye, or simply stitch. Linens, cottons, silk, batiste,laces, trims, threads. these are not perfect, just perfectly imperfect. these are fabrics of peoples lives.

each collections is different, some are similar. if you order more than one 1 will make sure yours are different within the collections. each contains larger pieces of ground fabric in silk, cotton, and linen and smaller pieces and fragments of others containing lovely handworked edges, laces, and trims. a little silk and cotton thread too...

Oh if cloth could talk!  Wait a minute- it can! what do you hear, see, and feel?

right now i have only 6 made up and ready to ship but a HUGE pile of lovely things awaiting my daily sorting, ironing, and gleaning. so give me a little time to make them up daily as they sell. 
enjoy!

name: indigo sky on cotton
description:
1/2 yard indigo sky on cotton lawn.  


all triple rinsed/washed/dried and ironed

the patterns are random and great for inspiring and dreaming.  think of lying on your back on a grassy hill looking at clouds in the sky...what do you see?

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: dyeable vintage silk
description:
-each bundle contains 3 plus meters of vintage silk kimono lining fabric  from Japan. each of the 3 meters is different.

imperfections exist but these silks have a history-and an intention. they have been saved all these years ( from 50-100!) and yet they are mostly overlooked in favor of the fancier outer and more decorative kimono fabrics.

these silks come from inner kimono linings and nagajuban (the under kimono that comes in contact with the skin) and are made of the softest and thinnest silks- and they dye beautifully with both acid dyes and indigo.

there are some stains and spots, needle marks and threads along the edges from being taken apart. these are fabrics that have been used and loved. 

this is cloth with character, waiting for your creativity to bring it back to life for the next 50-100 years.

name: indigo blue fabric assortment
description:
set of lovely indigo dyed pieces from sample making in the online workshop.  using 4 different vats and a variety of techniques. 

assorted fabrics new and old. cotton, linen, silk, solids, trims, threads, patterns.

great for what-iffing and wondering. a stitchers delight.

we are holding blue hands around the world! 

each pack is unique, of course.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: silk shibori ribbon scrap bags
description:
2.5 yards of assorted cuts and colors of silk shibori ribbon.  
like a wildflower mix. 


please visit the blog ( www.shiborigirl.wordpress.com ) to download the instructions to the simple shibori flower.

name: indigo dyed vintage fabric collection
description:
all vintage fabrics like the ones in the white vintage collections but blue!  dyed in my natural fermentation vat these ample packs include cotton, linen, silk, maybe some rayon, laces, trims, threads and such.
so many blues from the same vat interpreted by many different cloths.

fabrics of our lives include pieces from clothing, household linens, farm cloth, and generally cloth people have used in their everyday lives.  

cloth with character and history- but now blue! 

dyed, rinsed, ironed, sorted and assembled ready to stitch and wonder.

only 4 packs up to ship right now. i've added a "make me one" feature in the drop down menu. expect the make me one feature to ship in a week or so. have to iron, sort and assemble those.

this yardage was dyed in a 100% natural indigo fermentation vat.

the linen is 3.8 oz and is 54" wide

each yard includes an indigo moon to light the way

name: reflections on Japanese silk(scarf)
description:
indigo dyed scarf on vintage nagajuban silk with woven pattern.  motifs include clouds, water, maple leaves, flowers and bamboo.  
dyed using both my natural fermentation vats, one end is a deeper blue than the other.  

the flattering diagonal hem is hand stitched with silk thread before dyeing.  If you like, I can add a simple bead to each end- you decide and let me know! 

aprox. size 14" x 75"

name: Silk Shibori Ribbon by the Yard
description:
My silk shibori pleated ribbon is made using 4" bias silk ribbon and has been shibori dyed and pleated. Pleating brings the ribbon to aprox. 1" wide adding an additional dimension to your work.
Both the color and texture is steam set rendering the color washfast and lightfast and the pleating semi-permanent. You may wish to alter the texture with a light shot of steam from your iron or remove it completely by ironing flat on a silk steam setting to reveal the lovely shibori dye pattern.

Use this luscious ribbon to fashion beautiful silk flowers, embellish a special garment or quilt, or work into a surface design or bookbinding project. 

Visit my blog at www.shiborigirlstudios.com to find where I am teaching classes on shibori and ribbonwork or to see more of my textile practice.

See my set of silk shibori ribbon flowers on Flickr for other ribbon ideas and inspiration.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/gdolce/sets/72157600716925873/

the ribbon is sold by the yard. choose colorways as desired

each order includes an instruction sheet for the basic single and double shibori ribbon flower with leaf.

name: Shibori Techniques on Silk-ONLINE  Self Study WORKSHOP
description:
This is a repeat of the 5 week class that began March 9,2011.

This workshop series focuses on shibori techniques for silk using the Colorhue dyes.    That is not to say that you are limited to using silk or this dyeset.  In fact, much of what is covered in this workshop can be applied to other fabrics as well as other dyesets.  It is not about dyes per say but all questions are welcomed.  (My personal experience/expertise is in the areas of acid dyes on silk and indigo on natural fibers so questions using MX or Procion dyes will not be covered-but anything in my area of knowledge is welcome.) I use the Colorhue dyes for demonstration purposes as they are simple, accessible, and non-toxic.  They can be used without the need to set up a whole dye studio but will only work on protein fibers. You can order your materials yourself or use what you have on hand and are comfortable with.  (you can order the colorhue dye at http://www.photoezsilkscreen.com/dyes.htm )

We will cover many shibori techniques-itajime, arashi, several stitched techniques, as well as some invented ones! This is a technique class and as such is not project based.  I will be using video that I shot a year ago ( they go with the lesson as it is written and photographed) and have added a few new videos along the way. 

This class will be hosted on a private blog like forum where you can post your work and interact with other participants. Lessons are pdfs with additional videos. All video links are permanent, you may refer to them any time.

In this repeat of this class, all lessons are already posted and you can go in and see what other students created the first time round. You will also have the option of sharing your work online and asking questions on the class blog.   PDF's can be downloaded and printed and the videos can be watched anytime.  This class is internet based so consider your ability to watch internet video and downloading PDF's before signing up. 

Since this is a repeat of this class, no new material will be offered and due to time constraints, I will offer comments and answer questions as I can.  You will receive one email at  the time of signup with your password with instructions and it will be up to you to progress through the lessons on your own.


Prerequisites for this class include a sense of wonder and a willingness to get creative and have some fun!

name: let's dye with indigo!
description:
5 lesson online workshop
ongoing...continuing

Return to the days of magical thinking, of childlike thinking, of tinkering, wondering, and creating. Together, let's keep a skylike mind and explore the possibilities! Let's dye with indigo!

This is a 5 week online exploration of indigo dyeing featuring practical information based on my now 5 year obsession with this blue dyestuff.

Most of what I know, I know through trial and error and I am still learning. I have kept the same vat going for 5 years now and have experimented  with various other types of vats as well.  I have traveled to Japan to work and learn from an indigo dyer there and took what I learned in that brief time to heart.  If you take this class, be prepared to fall in love...with indigo.

The five weeks will look something like this:
week one
-making and maintaining various types of indigo vats and the differences I have encountered with each. Choosing the type of vat that suits your needs and circumstances. We will start off the class by dyeing a yard of sky fabric- in keeping with my 2012 philosophy of maintaining a "skylike mind".
week two
-itajime patterning with indigo: small and large cloth
week three
stitched shibori and indigo: tips, design, and learning patience
week four
-creating cloth for contemporary boro- moons, stars and other techniques
week five
-ombre dyeing with indigo and combining this with other techniques for stunning and unusual results.
 
there will be some surprises along the way! 

Materials:

materials will consist of basic ingredients for the type of indigo vat you choose to work with, various natural fabrics you wish to use, as well as basic dye and shibori equipment/materials. Upon signing up for the workshop you will gain access to the blog by registering for a free WordPress username (you may already have one) where Lesson One will discuss and help you choose the type(s) of vats you want to work with and the materials needed.  If needed, help accessing a WordPress username will be provided. 

Class includes audio, video, PDFs, and blog hosted workshop.  Please consider your ability to access these aspects of the class and your internet speed.  (Some who have slower access may need to let video load first before watching.) 

The workshop  is hosted on a private WordPress blog like with a separate attached student forum where you can post your work and interact with other participants. Lessons include PDFs, videos and audio. All video links are permanent, you may refer to them any time.

Prerequisites for this class include a sense of wonder and a willingness to get creative and fall in love...with indigo!

Allow 24 hours from time of purchase to be added to the workshop.

Continuing posts will be focused on the fermentation vat ans growing and composting indigo.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: the daily dyer
description:
This is a subscription to my new site, the daily dyer-a daily visit into my dye studio. The making and dyeing I do on a daily basis.  

Viewable by subscription only ( in 6 month increments), it is not meant to be a class in the traditional sense but a view of what it means to practice dyeing for a living on a daily basis. A way to travel in time perhaps...

Posts are added daily with no set schedule.  Knowing that there are days when I am not in the studio, some posts will be randomized. There will be about 5 posts a week.

Most posts will be in the form of a short video, shot in and around the studio and offer what you might consider “a view from the dyepot” and include tips and musings on indigo and acid dyeing as well as silk, textiles and whatever is happening as I continue to wonder... what comes next.

Maybe you'd like to come wonder along with me.
 
Audio and video format. Please consider your ability to view video via the internet before purchasing (most daily videos will be under 2 min.) The Daily Dyer takes place on a private Wordpress blog and you will receive instruction on accessing it within 24 hours of your purchase.

Email me for payment options outside of paypal. 
Allow 24 hours to receive an email invite via Wordpress to access the site using your own free Wordpress account/login. You may already have one!


The original daily dyer begins December 15 and continues through 
June 15, 2013. 

Continuing viewers- please choose "continuing" in the drop down menu at $35.
New viewers-this purchase will allow you access to the full year- $95.

The Daily Dyer will be active through Dec. 31, 2013.

name: vintage washi cocoon bags
description:
As described in the post entitled "back to the future again", these washi cocoon bags are estimated to be older than 100 years.  Made from handmade plant fibers likely from the Mino city area of Japan.

they were most likely used to transport cocoons to filature mills.  they are large- aprox. 32" x 60".  

Please go the the blog post for further details:

http://shiborigirl.wordpress.com/2013/02/15/back-to-the-future-again/

use the drop down menu to make a choice- they are listed in the order that the photos appear.

Magnetic clasp for easy wearing.

(hand dyed...just one)

name: undeniably elegant, recognizably unique, full of wonder
description:
silk satin shibori, silver and abalone shell.

handmade

the abalone shell is a memory from takasaki, japan.  served live at an elegant dinner for 4 where silk and dyeing was the topic of discussion. 
we donned our yukatas, sat with old friends, & sake flowed.

we discussed the future, we wondered, we enjoyed.

the silk cording is hand dyed shibori, everything hand sewn (of course) and filled with yet another hand dyed and pleated ivory silk satin ribbon. the silk shibori ribbon mimics the natural colors of the abalone shell. 

the findings are silver, the clasp magnetic. reversible. 22"

silk shibori, silver, and shell.
seems like a perfect combination!

free shipping

name: Ready to Wear Again-mending service
description:
We can talk about it or we can do it. We can mend and repair or we can throw away and buy brand new. 

You may have bought them new or found them in a second hand shop. They may have been given as a gift or handed down. 

They have been worn and through the wearing they have become comfortable in all the right places. They still fit. 

But, they are worn and have a few holes. And, in some places the fabric has thinned. 

The great abundance of things at our fingertips temps us to forget the value of caring for the things that we do have and the way we can make more of that which we already have in our possession. 

You might want to send them off (washed first, please) to have them mended in the spirit of the of the Japanese of the Tohoku region who struggled to make ends meet and through that struggle made life more alive by making and using every last bit of the necessities in their lives. 
In doing this, though they could not see into the future, they left us with their beautiful boro-tattered rags. They gave meaning to this mending through the layers of cloth and the stitch work they applied.    In these times, we can be reminded of the precious qualities of life and the necessities of things like clothing and feeding ourselves and taking better care.

Here is what I offer: one hour of my time to stitch and repair your pair of loveworn jeans using a variety of my own indigo hand dyed scraps and threads and a piece or two of my own boro scraps collected in Japan.  I will decide how and where to stitch, and return them to you via priority mail-insured.  Upon purchasing this service, I will email you the shipping address.  

If you want to mend them yourself, you may want to purchase the option “mending kit” which includes 6 various indigo patches and the thread to stitch with plus a needle.  All  you will need is a quiet moment and a pair of scissors.

(I just added a "double" mending kit for an extra $5.  folks were asking for enough to cover their own buttons or do a bit of "letting out" on their favorite jeans)
see last couple of new photos added...

~all fabrics and threads are recycled and dyed in my own natural fermentation indigo vat. (aside from the Japanese boro scraps). 

(note- if your jeans need two hours worth of mending simply purchase two)

Continental US only. Please allow 2 weeks for mending.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: Silk Shibori Pocket Square
description:
The word charmeuse comes from the French verb "charmeur" which means "charming". These silk shibori pocket squares made of 100% silk charmeuse will add a little "charming" to any jacket pocket.

Hand dyed and pleated using the arashi shibori technique, these pocket squares can be manipulated into interesting shapes and tucked into a jacket pocket, adding a splash of color and a touch of style to your wardrobe.

This 17 x 17" design takes the pocket square even further.  The silk square is run through the process twice to achieve the cross directional texture and dyed design after undergoing a base dyeing and a discharge process.

hence the higher price...

also available in natural indigo for $58...

enjoy each one for it's uniqueness! remember, no two are ever alike!

name: Indigo Mandala workshop-online
description:
This Mandala Workshop is a collaboration of Richard Carbin and Glennis Dolce.  

Richard’s US workshop in February of 2012 at Shibori Girl Studios combined Richard’s  mandala technique with Glennis’ indigo dye experience.  This workshop is a collaboration between us from opposite sides of the globe!

While this technique can also be applied to other fabrics and dye sets, this workshop focuses on making indigo mandalas and is suggested to be taken as an adjunct to Glennis’ “Let’s Dye with Indigo” online workshop. The intricacies of indigo dyeing are many and this workshop does not cover those topics. It will be assumed that you have the knowledge to successfully dye with indigo.

Class includes audio, video, PDFs, and blog hosted workshop. Please consider your ability to access these aspects of the class and your internet speed. (Some who have slower access may need to let video load first before watching.)


•	Supplies
•	Fabric Preparation
•	Dyeing the Mandala
•	Results and Variations

Class posts and blog opens June 1.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: purple haze
description:
100% silk. 3.5mm silk gauze with silk satin bias ribbon edging. i never tire of making these when they come out like this. 

base dyed in purple, discharged and overdyed. no two alike! steam set for colorfastness and texture. arashi shibori
36" x 54"

please dry clean only to preserve pleating.

I can also make green haze, black haze, and probably a few other hazy combos- just ask.

open weave cotton, ombre indigo dyed, raw fringe on 3 sides, with patches of silk (old kimono lining), shibori and linen. hand stitched with indigo silk floss.  a hand dyed indigo moon is of course, included. Each one is unique and will be made to order but will closely resemble this one.

should i say any more?  if you need more, just email me. please allow 2 weeks for me to create yours.

aprox. 24" x 72"

hand washable

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: 3 moon assortment
description:
just 3 assorted moons. at least one red moon included.

fabrics vary- old kimono silk from the lining of an old kimono, some old wool i've been keeping around for something special, some of that great old handspun handwoven linen, silk organza, and a few other tasty fabrics that were handy.


handpainted, itajime shibori and indigo dyed... all are about 5" square.

consider joining the online indigo class if you want to make your own...

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: indigo wall panel-Sold
description:
13.5 x 50 " 
indigo shibori on cotton

mounted on a bamboo textile hanger from indonesia or vietnam...can't remember.
can be purchased with or without hanger.

techniques- tied resists and ombre dyeing in assorted vats.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: twin indigo moons
description:
this is a pair of moons- one transparent on silk organza and the other on soft cotton scrim. both have transparent qualities. like the once twin moons of jupiter or perhaps the twin moons of the fictional tatooine...

 aprox fabric size-one is about 3-3.5" the other is 5"

my series of indigo shibori moons was born out of a variety of inspirations- midnight moonlit bike rides through the neighborhood on warm summer nights, the rhythms of the seas and tides, the inky metallic color of a working indigo vat...to name a few.
a trip last year to Japan where i had the privilege of working under a master indigo dyer not only taught me patience and respect for the materials and process but also inspired some new thinking about shibori in general.  
the moons represent the passage of time- i am now 17 blue moons young! i often work in my outdoor studio into the night watching the moon rise overhead.  i look up and wonder if Sato sensei is working under the same moon...

there are never any two moons alike. each moon undergoes many dips into the indigo vat-each dip adding a layer of intention. as i wait for the indigo to oxidize, i look and contemplate my next step.
the moons are dyed on various scrap and vintage cloth collected and given to me from friends-cottons,linens,silks-fine scraps from clothing,table linens, & textile collectors. i love discovering the many varied ways in which the indigo friends each fabric.

if ordered alone, these will be sent first class mail without tracking-otherwise feel free to add them to any order with no additional shipping cost.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: shades of indigo
description:
lovely shades of blue on cotton lawn  or other lightweight cottons suitable for stitching and creating. 

1/2+ (45" wide) yard dyed in 3 shades of blue in the fermentation vat
(total yardage 1.5 yards)

triple rinsed (used the rinse water for the garden),  line dried.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: blue solstice-SOLD
description:
stars and moon, sea and sky, shiny things that catch the eye.

stitched in silk with various indigo fabrics-some vintage boro from japan, a shibori snowflake-some trinkets from the shore...

 enough to make you wonder-

to celebrate a blue solstice-this year, december 22nd.

(if ordered by noon Dec.19 i can ship priority mail USPS same day(the 19th) for you to receive on the 22nd.)

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: indigo pillow
description:
14 x 14 pillow with indigo dyed and hand stitched envelope style cover.

boro inspired and using fabrics dyes here in the indigo vats while teaching the online indigo class.  

had a few of my old porcelain buttons in blue to add...so i did.

just simple.  but true- blue.

US shipment only unless you just want the cover for your own pillow.  email me.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: december full moon eclipse-5 moons
description:
i was inspired to make these moons and eclipsed moons as a result of seeing the NASA video on the  december 2011 full moon eclipse happening early tomorrow morning (beginning at 4:45 PST).  

i made red moons before but the NASA film explained the science behind the red color during a full eclipse as well as the appearance of a slight turquoise edge that may appear at the beginning of the cycle. 

i wondered how that might look...

the color is due to light refracting from dust in the earth's atmosphere and can vary in intensity.  

i've used some old kimono silk from the lining of an old kimono, some old wool i've been keeping around for something special, some of that great old handspun handwoven linen, silk organza, and a few other tasty fabrics that were handy.

i'm putting these up in two different combinations- a 3 moon assortment and a 5 moon assortment.  
both will be a combination of fabrics and moons-both red eclipsed moons and shaded full moons. 

handpainted, itajime shibori and indigo dyed... all are about 5" square.

i hope you are able to view the moon in the morning-i'll be looking at it with you.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: indigo moon necklace-SOLD
description:
simple beginnings

...a penny moon 
hemp and linen scraps
a dark scrap of boro-a gift from richard in japan
a few silver miyuki drop beads
pewter slide bail and bead caps
magnetic clasp
cotton cording
a bit of crinoline
a wooden toothpick
indigo

~silk thread hand stitched in almost invisible tiny stitches.  you can wear this long or short. the bail slides on the cord to adjust.

~overall length of the hemp wrapped cord is 32". ( i can adjust this if desired)  

the cord is cotton wrapped in fringed hemp that i indigo dyed with the arashi shibori pattern.  

the fabrics here show both their warp and weft, the fringed edges add to the effect. 

no matter how or where we are, we all share the same moon.

we'll share the shelter, we'll share the moon.

name: Kantan silk shibori scarf
description:
Although the folding, pleating, and dyeing give it a complex look, this silk shibori scarf is very easy to wear.

Originally 12" x 60" before pleating it wears close to the neck, filling in a wide variety of simple necklines. Each scarf is hand dyed by me in my California studio using the arashi (pole wrapped) method. Pleats and dyes are steam set.

To wear, first wrap around the neck and tie a loose overhand knot. Next, pick up a pinch of fabric from the edge of each side of scarf and tie a second overhand knot with just that pinch of fabric and pull up snugly against the first knot.  Each time you tie it it will form a unique and beautiful sculptural shape. 

I have added a download to this item that gives you a link to a youtube video I made demonstrating the tying of this piece. You can see it here by copying and pasting this link:
http://youtu.be/igTcXRRLWxI

100% silk with swarovski crystals stitched to the tips- dry cleanable.

wear and enjoy fabulously!

**color selection**
in second image starting at the top left and moving clockwise:
~purple mountains
~fall orchids
~carnelian
~it's complicated

Don't see your perfect color combo? Then choose "let's work it out" and I will contact you following your purchase to make one to order.
Please expect 2 weeks for this option.

name: Pocket Candy (aka silk shibori pocket squares)
description:
The word charmeuse comes from the French verb "charmeur" which means "charming". These silk shibori pocket squares made of 100% silk charmeuse will add a little "charming" to any jacket pocket.

Hand dyed and pleated using the arashi shibori technique, these pocket squares can be manipulated into interesting shapes and tucked into a jacket pocket, adding a splash of color and a touch of style to your wardrobe.

Each silk shibori pocket square is one of a kind as is the nature of shibori. Available in a wide variety of 2 tone colors or even solids. 

when calling out colors for the "name your color" selection, during checkout please list the colors desired in the comment to seller box.
If there is any question, email me at shiborigirl@shiborigirlstudios.com.

base colors available:
Blue
Chartreuse
Red
Orange
Black
Turquoise
Yellow
Green
Rust

*other colors available upon request

I will choose the overdye color unless something specific is requested. Not all color combinations are possible due to limitations of the dyeset. 
I will honor specific color combination requests to the best of my ability. Past customers have been very pleased with their color combinations and trust in my color sensibilities. 

currently- all pocket squares are now aprox. 17" x17" as the smaller ones have become too inconsistent to meet my standards and men have been telling me they prefer them. 

-for more info and descriptions on my pocket squares you can go to my blog at:
http://shiborigirl.wordpress.com/pocket-squares/

I also keep a facebook page for them with current updates on newly dyes squares and other pocket lore at:
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Silk-Shibori-Pocket-Squares-by-Shibori-Girl/49445528089

Enjoy!
glennis

name: silk shibori ribbon flower brooch kit
description:
Use my hand dyed silk shibori ribbon to make this simply beautiful floral brooch for yourself. Re-use the instructions and order more ribbon to make flowers for friends and family as a lovely one of a kind gift or for a special occasion.

Simple to make yet wonderfully unique, all you need in addition to the materials listed below are needle, thread, and scissors. Instructions for both the double and single flower are provided (materials herein are for the double flower).

The magnetic bar back is self adhesive and eliminates having to fuss and fumble with tiny pinbacks and putting holes in that favorite blouse or lapel. With the mag bar, you can wear the flower in your hair, clip it onto a hat or handbag, or even use it on a necklace. To remove, simply slide mag bar back aside on one end first and pull away from flower. 
(NOT FOR USE WITH A PACEMAKER!) To use, place magbar underneath flower with fabric (jacket, blouse, scarf, etc.) between and clip on.

Kit includes Shiborigirl Silk Shibori ribbon (18" for flower & 6" for leaf), self adhesive magnetic bar back (for use as a broach instead of a pinback), beads for flower center, silk batting filler, and instructions that include a video link.

name: poinsettia materials kit with instructions
description:
this is the materials kit for the poinsettia broach which includes the instruction download.

the materials kit includes:

*1 yard of holiday red silk shibori ribbon
*1 bead pack for flower center
*enough green silk organza for 3 leaves
*one mag bar for making the piece into a broach
*silk batting as needed

when purchasing the materials kit, the PDF instruction download is free.  

please note, all written and video instructions are copyrighted and not for distribution by anyone other than myself. 

i hope you enjoy making, wearing and giving these lovely holiday broaches!

name: poinsettia instructions only
description:
this is the DOWNLOAD ONLY for making the poinsettia floral broach. 

the instruction is formatted as a PDF with video links. please consider your ability to watch internet media when purchasing. 

PLEASE NOTE:
there is a separate listing for both this download AND the materials kit to make the poinsettia.  if you wish to purchase both, see listing marked 
" materials kit AND instructions".

please note, all written and video instructions are copyrighted and not for distribution by anyone other than myself.

thanks!

name: holiday red silk shibori ribbon by the yard
description:
just basic yardage of the red shibori ribbon used to make the poinsettias.

order 3 yard packs and get a price break! i'll also include a yard of the green silk organza for the leaves.  

don't have a photo just for the red at the moment but you can see the color in the poinsettia photo-

name: poinsettia brooch
description:
one day i wondered...

what if i used some really glorious red silk shibori ribbon and tried to make some poinsettia flowers...

they take a little time but i think they look quite festive.

let's celebrate!

each one is a little bit different but equally lovely.  
aprox. 4"-5" tip to tip with a magnetic back so you can clip them into place without damaging your fabric.

(not to be used with a pacemaker...please request barpin version if needed)

please allow a week for one to be made especially for you.

if you want to make your own, there is also a kit with instructions

name: Shibori Girl gift certificate-$any amount
description:
a nice way to give a gift of their choice. available in the amount of your choice j!ust click the image below and it will take you to where you can fill out the details and complete your purchase. do not put this item in your cart.

and thank you!

name: wired silk shibori necklace and flower instructions only
description:
This is a 3 lesson downloadable instruction in PDF form on how to make this wired shibori ribbon necklace and flower.

With the techniques you practice here, once you have made one you will come up with variations of your own and be inspired to create many more for family and friends.

I will also put into the shop a materials kit for your convenience with the parts needed to make one. You can order the ribbon separately.

name: indigo silk organza diffusion
description:
silk organza ribbon with stitched overlock on both sides has been dyed with a new technique i'm practicing with indigo.  a little tricky but with beautiful and mesmerizing results.  like oil based ink dropped into swirling water. no two inches alike.  

2 yards per package with an extra yard of solid sky blue thrown in for contrast. 

(4" wide) total yardage is 3 yards per pack. email me if you want larger lots or lengths.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: Shibori Dragonfly Pin KIT
description:
This is the full kit for the silk shibori dragonfly pin and includes the ribbon, beads, wire, and bar pin that you will need.

Additional supplies include:
scissors, wire cutter (or craft scissors), pliers, needle (your preference-I use a long fine milliners or beading needle), thread (invisible or matching), bead mat if handy or desired (saves me from hunting the floor or carpet for wayward beads) .

Your choice of ribbon color can be noted below.  You will receive instructions to download the PDF instructions immediately to your computer to print at your leisure.  The materials kit will be shipped within one to two days M-F.  Allow extra time over weekends.

The making of this shibori ribbon dragonfly came as a result of a dream I had.  The dream involved a family member who transformed into a dragonfly and came to tell me of his future plans.  Over the next several days, dragonflies kept appearing in various forms- to the point that I had to notice.  Sitting down working on some ribbon flowers it occurred to me to make a butterfly, then of course, the dragonfly.  Since then, dragonflies have continued to appear in some very interesting ways.  One particular event still has me wondering.  I’m not trying to understand it all, I’m just paying attention. 

Wondering what dragonfly lore existed, I did a little googling.  I found lots of references and among them stories and beliefs that the dragonfly represents an agent of change, of wisdom and enlightenment. I also read of how the iridescent wings of a dragonfly- which allow it to be seen in different colors depending on the angle and polarization of light falling on them-are symbolic of casting off one’s self illusions and unmasking the real self (whom of us couldn’t use a little of that?).  In other words, it’s a flight of real self-discovery.  Also the dragonfly’s relationship to water interests me.  

Whatever the meaning, I’m just noticing.  And listening. So I wrote up these instructions and photographed the steps.  I hope you enjoy making one or two…

name: dragonfly-tonbo-屯簿 brooch
description:
~silk shibori ribbon dragonfly pin with beaded body (aprox. 4.5" wing span)

(these are pinback brooches-not magnetic as the magbar doesn't work well with these creatures-too large and heavy.  these guys are light and airy!)


The making of this shibori ribbon dragonfly came as a result of a dream I had.  The dream involved a family member who transformed into a dragonfly and came to tell me of his future plans.  Over the next several days, dragonflies kept appearing in various forms- to the point that I had to notice.  Sitting down working on some ribbon flowers it occurred to me to make a butterfly, then of course, the dragonfly.  Since then, dragonflies have continued to appear in some very interesting ways.  One particular event still has me wondering.  I’m not trying to understand it all, I’m just paying attention. 

Wondering what dragonfly lore existed, I did a little googling.  I found lots of references and among them stories and beliefs that the dragonfly represents an agent of change, of wisdom and enlightenment. I also read of how the iridescent wings of a dragonfly- which allow it to be seen in different colors depending on the angle and polarization of light falling on them-are symbolic of casting off one’s self illusions and unmasking the real self (whom of us couldn’t use a little of that?).  In other words, it’s a flight of real self-discovery.  Also the dragonfly’s relationship to water interests me.  

Whatever the meaning, I’m just noticing.  And listening. 

Enjoy these dragonfly pins for yourself, or as a special gift to someone exhibiting dragonfly qualities!

I am also including as a bonus a free download of the instructions....just in case you are tempted to make some as gifts yourself.

name: Shibori Dragonfly Pin-Downloadable Instructions only
description:
These are instructions only for the shibori ribbon dragonfly pins.  Upon purchasing this item you will receive instructions immediately to download the 4 page instructions with color photos.  If you have any questions or problems, email me at shiborigirl@shiborigirlstudios.com

The full kit version of this is available separately and also includes these instructions.


The making of this shibori ribbon dragonfly came as a result of a dream I had.  The dream involved a family member who transformed into a dragonfly and came to tell me of his future plans.  Over the next several days, dragonflies kept appearing in various forms- to the point that I had to notice.  Sitting down working on some ribbon flowers it occurred to me to make a butterfly, then of course, the dragonfly.  Since then, dragonflies have continued to appear in some very interesting ways.  One particular event still has me wondering.  I’m not trying to understand it all, I’m just paying attention. 

Wondering what dragonfly lore existed, I did a little googling.  I found lots of references and among them stories and beliefs that the dragonfly represents an agent of change, of wisdom and enlightenment. I also read of how the iridescent wings of a dragonfly- which allow it to be seen in different colors depending on the angle and polarization of light falling on them-are symbolic of casting off one’s self illusions and unmasking the real self (whom of us couldn’t use a little of that?).  In other words, it’s a flight of real self-discovery.  Also the dragonfly’s relationship to water interests me.  

Whatever the meaning, I’m just noticing.  And listening. So I wrote up these instructions and photographed the steps.  I hope you enjoy making one or two…

name: all of it-plus moons
description:
this is the choice for those who want some of both- the transparent indigo fabric pack and the 3 patterns and a solid.  

you will get 1/2 yd of each of the patterns shown (on cotton lawn) and 1/4 of the med. silk noil solid.
-total of 1.75 yards in 4 different pieces of indigo fabric
plus:
1/4 yd of light blue cotton scrim
1/4 yd of med blue cotton scrim
1/4 yard of silk organza mysteriously dyed with lights and darks
1/4 yd (narrow yardage) of hemp/silk ombre dyed
-total of 1 yard in 4 different fabrics

**i may substitute in different patterns/fabrics as each dye session produces unique fabrics but total yardage will be the same.  

all triple rinsed/washed/dried and ironed

 sometimes transparent means that light can pass through and you can see on through to the other side, sometimes it means that something is invisible and unable to be seen.  the choice is ours.

the patterns are random and great for inspiring and dreaming.  think of lying on your back on a grassy hill looking at clouds in the sky...what do you see? 

plus you get two indigo moons- one in cotton and one in silk organza.

categories.name: indigo and other naturally dyed cloth and thread

name: oh poppycock!
description:
~floral broach in reds, melons, and pinkish tones.  silk chiffon and silk organza.
shibori and various dye techniques. hand stitched, magnetic back suitable for clipping onto a garment, in your hair, on a hat or handbag.

3.5"

name: aiko-SOLD(missing)
description:
she is the first aiko- a love child. in japanese, ai means love and ko means child. ai is also the word for indigo…but different kanji.
first of a series. signed and numbered. all indigo dyed. hair of raw silk, head of a silk cocoon. 

hand stitched with ai.

she is also a good listener.

*signed and marked as aiko 1

name: floral fantasy
description:
larger than life (5.5") is made of all hand dyed silk shibori fabrics.  arashi, and bomaki techniques combined on silk satin and lightweight habotai dyed in pinks and purples.

carefully hand stitched, this piece would make a great companion to a garden or summer party- on a hat or garment, to close a scarf or shawl or even clipped into your hair.  the magnetic back makes this simple without poking a hole in your fine wearables.  



contact me to order something custom made for your special occasion.

name: sea anemone necklace-SOLD
description:
shibori on transparent iridescent poly takes the form of a sea anemone.  this one stitched onto silk shibori ribbon (colorway ecru borealis) in an art to wear necklace.  

sea anemones tend to stay in the same spot until conditions become unsuitable whereupon they can detach themselves and swim away to a new location.  not unlike ourselves i think.

this piece has an easy to use magnetic clasp, is 24" (i could shorten it if you like) and is hand dyed and hand stitched.  

it requires a simple neckline and would be fun to wear to a gathering of creative sorts.  it also just happens to look cool sitting around!

one of a kind.
